newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexican peso hit badly by anxiety, speculators.
newsitem.headline: Mexican peso hit badly by anxiety, speculators.

text.p: The Mexican peso closed down across the board Tuesday, battered again by anxiety and speculation that expectations of higher rates at today's T-bill auction did nothing to arrest, traders said.

"What triggered the speculation and jitters that led to a run on the peso? That's quite a question when you consider that such sharp changes in the exchange rate are unnerving when interest rates are on their way up," said a trader.
Traders expected Cetes rates to gain on the bellwether 28-day issue, but to be mixed on other issues at the primary auction being held today.
The benchmark 48-hour peso and its 24-hour counterpart closed 4.4 and 4.3 centavos weaker, respectively, at 7.7820/7.7900 and 7.7730/7.7830 per dollar.
The same-day peso had earlier closed 2.6 centavos weaker at 7.7460/7.7510 per dollar.
Some traders said a local bank stepped into the market to buy substantial amounts of dollars, which triggered a run on the peso.
"There was a bank out there that was very short (dollars), and the market got out of hand when it stepped in to cover positions," said a trader.
Traders said that rates assigned by Banco de Mexico at the primary Cetes auction would be crucial to how the peso would fare on Wednesday.
